title: How to Set Goals to Reduce Water Usage in Your Home

steps.headline: Set specific water reduction goals.
steps.description: For example, commit to using 20% less water per month.

steps.headline: Determine a baseline to start reducing from.
steps.description: Print the energy and water consumption chart and post it in a visible spot in your home. Chart the number of gallons of water used in the last 12 months (for comparison to each month this year).

steps.headline: Make specific changes in products used and family member habits.
steps.description: For example, buy water saving products where needed, such as a low-flush toilet and a water-saving showerhead.

steps.headline: Get your family involved by asking for specific changes in everyone's habits.
steps.description: For example, place signs near water outlets reminding family members to reduce consumption (e.g., shorter showers, turning the faucet off when not needed, only watering outdoor plants in the morning or evening).

steps.headline: Make adjustments.
steps.description: Once a month, add the new usage information to the charts and make adjustments as needed to reach your goals.

steps.headline: Use the money saved to do something fun with your family.
steps.description: If you have children, increase their allowances by the amount saved to encourage them to get involved in finding new ways to conserve.

Make specific changes in products used and family member habits. For example, buy water saving products where needed, such as a low-flush toilet and a water-saving showerhead. Make adjustments. Once a month, add the new usage information to the charts and make adjustments as needed to reach your goals. Use the money saved to do something fun with your family. If you have children, increase their allowances by the amount saved to encourage them to get involved in finding new ways to conserve.
